text:
PROFESSOR: I would like to
have a slightly different kind
of a pin-up today than usual.
And I'll explain.

You become very
connected to your work.

Sometimes you can't see
anything except your own work.

And you get into it so far
that you get lost or get--

let us say, you get hopelessly
lost inside your own project.

Perhaps not hopelessly, but
you certainly only see that.

And I'd like to have you
step back from that today

and see your project in a
little different way that is not

so connected personally
to you, so that maybe you

can be a little bit
more objective about it.

So the format for the
review is very simple,
but it gets at that notion.

And that is that you're
going to have a partner.

And I've teamed you up for
various reasons because--

same, sit together, or similar
project, or for whatever.

And we're going to have
about a 10-minute time.

So you're going to have
a teammate, first of all.
And I'll tell you who they are.

And you're going to have about
10 minutes to, both of you,

explain to each other
what your project is
and what was important.

So these are two
that are teamed up.

She explains what she's doing
to her project to Hassan.

And Hassan explains
what he's doing to her.

Then after that, I'm going
to ask, in this case, Hassan
to present her project.

And she has to
sit there quietly.

And then she presents
his floor project.

And further, I'm
going to ask them

to make one comment as to how
they could make it better.

So you're getting
outside yourself.
Got it?

GUEST SPEAKER 1:
So for instance,

let's say how she can
make her's better?

PROFESSOR: She is
presenting Hassan's, what
he's trying to do.

And at the end, she
says, I think that Hassan
could improve it by doing this.
And he's sitting there quietly.

He can't say, hey, that's
not the way I want to do it.
It was something else.
He has to remain quiet.
Got it?

So you can't jump in
and say, hey, this.

And then of course, we'll
have a discussion after that.

And the point of that is to get
you outside your own project,

so that you might be able to
see it in a different eye.
All right?

GUEST SPEAKER 2: You
probably remember

the skating and the rock
climbing as central ideas.

So she wanted to put that in
the central part of the building

and make the activities connect
the building vertically.

And so that from
everywhere in the building,

you can see down
into the skating
and to the rock climbing.

So I'll just take
you through it.
The entrance is here.
This is the street.
You come in like this.
You enter into here.

This is the food
area, which is clear.

And so it's visible
from the outside.
And you can come eat in here.
And these are circulation.

They're either going
to be ramps or stairs.
GUEST SPEAKER 1: Escalator.

GUEST SPEAKER 2: Or
escalator, sorry.

So the first floor
is mainly the food,

or you can go and pare
the rock climbing.

This is all
connected, obviously.

And the second floor has
an area for concerts.

The area is sort of the
rental area for climbing
and for skating, I guess.
You can rent.

And then the third
floor has more

of a learning for the climbing
area and the general hangout
spot.
Let's see.

In terms of materials, the
floor mainly is concrete.

This is actually transparent,
so you can look down
and see people skating by.

And it's right on top of
the skate paths, I guess.

And this part here is
more open because it wants
to focus on this big area.

The second floor is
more closed because it
has more of the rental area.

OK, the hangout spot
has a slanted window

because she wanted you
to be able to look down
onto everything but not be seen.

So that you're watching,
but you can just

be doing your own
thing at the same time.
Oh, right, the roofs.

The roofs also direct the
light into the main area
that she wanted to emphasize.

So light comes in through here
down, here down, here down.

And if you turn
this around, you can

see that there's actually
another entrance in here
to go into the food place.
And this floor extends out.

And so this is an area
that you can hang out.
And you can also enter here.

And so you can go rock
climbing out here or indoors.
And let's see.

Oh, one thing she
changed from last time

was that the walkway that
she had wrapping around,

you can now walk all the
way around the platforms.

Whereas before, she
had a platform end here
and another one start there.

So now you can walk
around the whole building.

So it's a horizontal connection
that puts everything together.

And as far as suggestions,
well, one suggestion

was maybe a more direct
path for the food

to this balcony hangout
area because right now, you
have to go--
[LAUGHTER]
GUEST SPEAKER 1: Hey.
[LAUGHTER]

GUEST SPEAKER 2: So that's a
suggestion to a practical one.

And well, I don't quite know
the structure of the roof
and how that's working.

I'm sure that'll be
figured out at some point.

And I don't know
the safety of this.

But it might be interesting
if you could keep going.

Because if you keep
climbing, you hit the roof.

And if you keep
climbing, you hit a roof.
It's cool just to keep climbing.

GUEST SPEAKER 1: Main idea
was she had researched
a lot of events go on.

A lot of parades take
place around this area.

And she wanted to make a place
where people can come together

from Boston and make
the floats in this area,

but also have tourists and
people, not necessarily making

them, observe the process
of making these floats.

So her buildings were
kind of organized

so that the public enters from
the stairs, from the right
here and goes--

the bottom floor is
a general art store,
so it's a very public area.

And then next most
public is the stairs

from the right for
the general public.

They enter through
the building in here.

And there's a museum,
and exhibition place,

and information
center, where they

can learn about the history
of Boston and stuff like that.

And there's a good
view from behind

of how they enter in
through this museum area,

across a ramp that looks
down over the space where

all the floats are being
built, which is the main--
a large area.

And you can continue
down that bridge

into this other area, which
is more museum and information
exhibition gallery space.

On the second floor in here,
with the clear windows,

and that also looks down
into this construction area.

GUEST SPEAKER 2:
It's very delicate.

GUEST SPEAKER 1:
And OK, so that's

where focus is
mainly on the public.

And then for the participants
for building the floats,

they enter through
this left side.

This glass box-like area
is all the circulation,

where all the stairs are to go
between the different levels.
So they enter from the left.

And the first floor,
there's this long hallway,

where there's wood shops,
metal shops that are all

open to this construction
area, the main construction
area in the middle.

And then on the second
floor was the gallery space.

But then, if the
builders of the floats

go up to the third
floor, there's

smaller rooms,
where they can focus

on building smaller components
of the larger float--

places for people to paint
things, stuff like that.

And then there's
a roof deck that

goes in the direction
of the street

that the parades or
the floats move down.

And there's also a
parallel deck over here.
That's for the public.

Her roofs are
designed to contrast

the more rectangular
plan of the building.

They kind of give the
illusion of floating

over a lot of
activity, signifying

all the different
construction and energy that's
going on underneath of it.

And a lot of lights
entering through here.

There's copper and
translucent material,
glass on the vertical openings.

So there's also a couple
of things we talked about,

where she maybe wants to develop
a better design for the roof

deck area, a different way to
maybe improve the circulation--

the area-- instead of
having the glass box.

But mainly, I think the roof
and the rest of the structure

is delicate, and interesting,
and pretty intricate.

But then you just kind
of have this thing

that's very literally
pointing out

to the street in this
rectangular shape.

So that can maybe match
the depth of design
for the rest of the project.
That's Laura's.
PROFESSOR: OK.
Very good, guys.
You two guys happy?
GUEST SPEAKER 1: Mm-hmm.

PROFESSOR: Maybe you should
hire each other to present.

It has the quality of least,
or has a quality of filters.
It has a lightness to it.

It has a quality of being an
incredible dynamic building.
This building is on the move.
And you have that feeling.

And it has the quality of
wanting to go in and see
what's going on in there.

It's very mysterious,
not in an opaque way.

But it has a
feeling of something

exciting is happening
inside of that.

And I think it's
very, very powerful.

Just the way the
roofs are and the way

that you've gone from the
copper, to the transparent,
to the clear.

When you turn it
around, you've got

this incredible lace-like fusing
of these small many members,

which are making this up,
which I think is terrific.
So it's a good start.

And it's so much
not on the scale.
This is like it's a real place.
You can imagine being in here.

And I'm sorry you didn't make
a float because it would've

been nice to see a
float inside of this
and get the scale of that.

Because the reason I
say that, is a float

also has this quality
of kind of a stage set
and so does the whole building.

So it would be nice to
see the two together.

I would just want to
say that, Stephanie, I
think you're right on.

There is what I call collision
architecture that we're now

seeing for the first time
between the wonderful lace-like

quality of the main
room and the other room.

And the connection
or, I will call it,

a dance between the two
is not yet resolved.

The dance between this-- look
at that, isn't that wonderful?

The dance between this and
this is very delicate right
in there.

And right there is
where it falls apart.

It's like somebody-- they hired
a very well-known architect
to do this.

And then they ran out of money
because she was so difficult.

It was so much for
her commission,

that I had to hire kind of a
hack architect to do this junk.

And you could care
less what she did.

And that's where it
shows up, right there.

GUEST SPEAKER 2:
Yeah, it actually
is supposed to be higher.
But it fell with the--
PROFESSOR: The roof?

GUEST SPEAKER 2:
--yeah, it doesn't hold.
PROFESSOR: OK.

Well, that's the
technical model probably.
GUEST SPEAKER 2: Yes.

PROFESSOR: But in
terms of design,

there is something that
isn't quite resolved.

Now, watch out because she
asked me the other day,

should the outlines
of this follow
the outlines of the roof.
No, it's two different systems.

So it is not that
geometry should in fact

govern everything that goes on,
it can be entirely different.

It is that there's a
dance between the two.

And this is what I
call the 10% solution.
It is not a major, major change.
It's actually a 5%.

It's just a slight, subtle
change, maybe this being lower

or being some of that geometry,
but very little into it.

And then you're home
free, so to speak.
We haven't seen the other side.

It will be nice now because
you've built almost all of it,
that you would do this.

Actually, all you have
to do is this right now.

The other thing that concerns
me is the incredible--
and it has always concerned me--

the incredible height for that
partition by the entrance way.
It's huge.
And there's-- is that it?
Is that somebody?
GUEST SPEAKER 2: That's, yeah.
PROFESSOR: Yeah, that's good.

That's a huge-- just in
terms of what you perceive,
it's quite large.

It could be-- not that we can
reduce to the height of that

because we've been
through this before,

because she's starting down
here with something that's OK,
and she's working her way up.

But it is possible that we
can break this facade, which

I think is going to be the
sub-theme of this afternoon.

You could break this facade into
maybe more translucent panels

or even opaque
panels up in here.

So we bring the scale down to
something that's more human.

I know this has to solve
the function of getting
huge floats out and people in.
But you can have both.

You can have your
cake and eat it, too.

You can have it from the human
scale and the flip scale,
so to speak.
So that's a couple of things.

Now if I come over
here, which is also

a remarkable piece of work
in terms of it's flowing.

You two got together
because of the roof thing.

You both have kinds
of floating roofs.

But this has an incredible
sense of flowing to it.

The skateboarders moving in and
out, like a pinball machine.
Everything happens.
It's incredible.

It's one more place that
you want to go to, just

to hang out to have
your lunch, even if you
don't like skateboarding.

Just I like to hang out
here on a winter day.

So there's an incredible
kind of flow in this, which
I think is very, very positive.

The thing that is so amazing,
is that the same person who

did this delicate flowing,
did this ugly staircase that
is just--
I mean it's-- outrageous.
It's kind of a slope.

I mean, nobody in
their right mind

is going to go up
that staircase.

And if there's a ramp, they're
just going to roll down.

So it's not very gentle,
whereas everything else

has an incredible feeling
to it of gracefulness, even
the skate park.

That doesn't, and that's
what was subtly hinted to,
I think, by your spokesperson.

So this staircase,
or whatever it

is, you said you turned
it into an escalator,
I think, by default.

But this thing
could wind its way

through that space as different
but one that goes where it was.
Yeah, it went through that.

And therefore, you could
sense that space more.

This is more like going
to get to your airplane
with your baggage on it.
You're going up something to--
it doesn't have that feeling.
So that's a complete miss to me.

The next thing is that
I think it was ingenious

of your spokesperson to
suggest if it's possible,

because it's kind of the idea
of you're building Stephanie,

that the skateboard people
are moving through it,

and under it, and out
into the copper tube that
was on the other mall.

I think it was
brilliant suggestion,

that if there was a way that
this thing could move out
of the building.
Maybe a little dangerous.

And how do you make the
enclosure there is not clear.

But it would be really neat
as a rope-- as a climber

to climb up out of the
building if I could do so.

And I don't know exactly how
you do that mechanically.
You have to figure that out.

But as opposed to
stopping it just--

and therefore, the vertical is
equivalent to the horizontal

because that's what's
happening in the vertical now.

Having said that, there's
some technical problems.

Somehow you've got to open
things up and close them.

Finally, you get the
award for the least

amount of roof held up by
something that we don't know.

I mean, the roof is
going to fly away.
It's very thin.
It's very flimsy.

And this, we get a feeling
that it's anchored back.
This one is not connected.
And it's so small.

Actually, all the
horizontal planes

are probably under
scale in this.

But particularly, the connection
between the gracefulness

of that roof, which has
got some size to it.

It's not just-- it's got to be
a little bit more than that.
GUEST SPEAKER 1: Yes.

Just for model making purposes,
I couldn't get them to glue
to the glass.

But really, it'll have
plastic, and then this

is the structure,
and then plastic
on the other side, sandwiched.

And it wouldn't be flat either,
so I just didn't glue them.

So they didn't have to have
them on there and be unsightly.

GUEST SPEAKER 2: Just
like your glass roof.

And this would almost
be like ammonia.
GUEST SPEAKER 1: Yeah.
PROFESSOR: Right.

Well then, if that's
the case, I still

think that, as a detail, where
the column is hitting this,

this gets filled in and
is taking the weight.
And it's not always streamlined.
I can't do it back.
[LAUGHTER]

GUEST SPEAKER 1: I think
you have a pointy thing.
Yeah, there you go.

PROFESSOR: Now the other thing
that I just want to mention,

that once again, and
again, I think this maybe

the topic of this afternoon
is there's so much more that

could be done with the
facade on this one also,

where there are just complete
planes of glass, which you
probably want in some cases.
You may have overdone it.

There could be places
where you could
break this down even more.

That is, it could be an upper
level for light to come in,

even the notion of light
shelves of bouncing light in
and then a lower level.

So these are relatively
simplistic kinds
of facade definitions.
But it's beautiful.
It's a great start.

The challenge for
both of these, is

how to keep this building, this
wonderful transparency that you

have that's inviting,
but at the same time,

controlling light and
access a little bit more.

Again, that is not like a
major change that you're in.

All of you are in the
area of minor changes
because the major that happened.
